support feet for duplicator type 3d printer.

I designed the support feet because my printer was fairly noisy and it kept moving while printing across the worktop.  Print two of each support, front left / rear right and front right / rear left. Your local DIY store will sell the rubber feet ( size 20mm * 8mm ) which you then glue or use double sided sticky tape inside the supports. the four corners are then pushed onto the printer ( see photo ) this then makes the printer quieter when printing and it does not move about.

title: Magnetic Vibration Isolation Feet
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
After much testing I was not able to get my printer to magnetically levitate. I'm leaving this up as Work in Progress in case someone wants to keep working on it.

These feet allow a 3D printer to be magnetically levitated to isolate the 3D printer from the surface it sits on. This may help reduce the operating noise of a running printer and will make your printer even cooler while it floats in mid-air.

Three sets of these feet can support my 10 lb delta printer with filament; I imagine they can support heavier printers but I haven't tested further. Those magnets can be purchased on Amazon; here's a link to get a twenty pack which has enough magnets to make up to four feet.

The foot and the insert are designed to accept two magnets each.

When printing these feet the print needs to pause before the magnet chamber is capped off. I recommend checking the layer number that starts the capping and putting a M226 or M0 right before the layer starts; insert the magnets when the pause happens and continue normally. The holes in the insert can be used to trap the insert inside the foot.

There are two versions of this print - one with the magnets at different heights in the insert and the outer foot and one with the magnets at the same level. The set with magnets at different heights is better because the magnets can be closer together but requires two different pauses if the insert and foot are printed together. I haven't tested the same-level set but they should work almost as well. The same-level set has "single pause" in the name.

I reworked jdmoto's mesh to use a thinner and less expensive magnet, capture the magnets, and better expose the inner workings.

Printer:

D300VS

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.3 mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Pause the print before the magnet chamber caps off and insert two magnets in each chamber. The magnets will need to be inserted in opposite orientation for correct effect - the insert should have it's magnet inserted upside-down relative to the foot. If they have the same orientation when installed you will create a magnetic piston toy.

title: Moducase - Modular enclosure for electronics. Designed for the Anet A8

description.text:
Update 8/12/17
I revised the covers and connecting splice due to a mis-alignment of the holes. I had printed them but didn't put them on until yesterday when I found out they were off 2-3mm in each direction. Trying to figure that one out.

Project now completely printed and done.

Update 8/1/17
I have printed this and fixed almost all errors. There is still misalignment with the mosfet mounting holes and the unit is 4-5 mm too wide to fit between the sides. I am planning to fix it when I have it apart the next time. The width is too much to fix.

This takes about 4 days to print and isn't for the faint at heart. However you will have a ton of room so it is your call.

There is the standard anet mounting plate and a RAMPS 1.4 mounting plate that adapts to the anet mounting holes in the files.

Update 5/3/17
I discovered during the design of a half case add-on that the holes for the original cover were wrong. I have removed the original cover file from the download and replaced it with the correct one. I also added a half size case with the needed side, cover, and cover splice.

If you design anything to be used with this, please make sure to put MODUCASE in the title so that way it is easy to find mounts/parts/accessories.

I am only offering the MKS mosfet and Anet A8 board mounts because that is all I have for measurements. Not because I don't want to do anymore.

Moducase V1.0
I grew frustrated over the fact that any enclosure didn't really have any room in them and they all had fixed mountings. Triangular shapes cut down on available space. Sure they might look nice but aren't practical.

So I designed this to be completely modular. Replaceable sides, covers, and mounts. The long sides are solid so you can mount a fan if you want or drill vent holes where you want them. You also have the option to drill for wire entry where you want it. They are square so you get more room. It is a tool, not the Easter dinner centerpiece.

You can also add these together in any configuration. Double, triple, you name it. Long or short sides together as well. The sides are 3mm thick (almost 1/8"). The bottom is 5mm thick.

No need to print a whole new enclosure because you messed up. Just print the part you need.

Remember that this is version 1. It might seem cumbersome but down the road if you upgrade or replace, then it could be as simple as reprinting some sides and maybe a cover. I am thinking about designing a simple pin instead of using screws and nuts.
Also I will be adding to the pictures section, the dimensions so if you want to design something different to go with it, you will have the measurements.

Tools and hardware you will need:

The holes are for M3 screws and nuts. You can countersink the heads if using flat-head screws. Amazon is a great source for M3 screws and nuts.

Metric hex keys

Metric drill bits (you can use standard but metric ones take some guess work out of it)

Countersink for screws (If using flat-heads). You can use for M3 screws as well. I recommend this style https://www.amazon.com/Countersink-Drill-Carpentry-Reamer-Woodwork/dp/B01H1D6FMA/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1493189234&sr=8-1-spons&keywords=countersink&psc=1 as they drill and counter sink all in one.

If you want just a countersink then this will work. https://www.amazon.com/Industrial-Center-Countersink-Degree-Included/dp/B00M54BPRQ/ref=sr_1_50?ie=UTF8&qid=1493189519&sr=8-50-spons&keywords=countersink&psc=1

Screwdriver or allen wrench for your screws.

A drill

Step bits https://www.amazon.com/HSS-Step-Drill-Bits-Danslesbls/dp/B01A6UTUKY/ref=sr_1_140?s=hi&ie=UTF8&qid=1493189970&sr=1-140&keywords=step+bit These work great to make any size hole you need and quite cheap.

If you have any design improvement ideas, email me or leave a comment.

Anet A8

1 long spacer if joining 2 together on the long sides as well as 1 more bottom, cover, and 2 short sides

According to a graphic I found on that bastion of Truth And Honesty (Facebook), this graphic is supposed to mean, "I wish to be with you until death." I don't speak (or read) Korean. I built the vector work in Corel Draw (because I stink at Inkscape) and copy/pasta'd into Inkscape. The bad photos are the result (on a speckled egg. Sorry 'bout that).
THIS WAS DRAFTED IN INKSCAPE 0.91 which has 1" defined as 90 DPI. Printing from Inkscape 0.92 will have it be too wide. Version 2 will be made... soon. Ish. When I get around to it.

1: Put egg in Egg-Bot. Adjust parts as necessary.
2: Put pen in Egg-Bot arm. Adjust parts as necessary.
3: Print. Adjust parts as necessary (if doing separate layers). Starting with this link: https://www.facebook.com/photo.php?fbid=400609266741582&set=a.252010398268137.60553.252006304935213&type=1
I copy/pasta'd the graphic from Facebook to Corel Draw, and made the Korean characters with boxes and ellipses, merging and then curving as appropriate. Once the Korean characters were made, I copy/pasta'd into Inkscape, and used Hershey Text for the English translation.
A hard boiled egg was loaded into my Egg-Bot. I used a Sharpie ultra-fine point marker. The file has since been edited to have the Korean characters in layer 1, and the English characters in layer 2 (my plan will be to have the Korean be in a bright, bold colour, and the English in a more muted tone, for the next time I print this).

title: Mojo Raspberry Pi Zero W portable music streamer player

description.text:
This is a Chord Mojo portable music streamer / player with a Raspberry Pi Zero W. Stream music / radio stations, play local stored files.

Hardware cost 21 usd + microsd card + printing cost ~30 usd :-).

It's a portable version of my Chord Mojo docking station, http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1716990 .

A universal version with a 18650 battery is here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2267531 .

I use a minimal linux version from RuneAudio (http://www.runeaudio.com/) to stream music from my nas/local storage to the Chord Mojo, using my phone with bubbleupnp/webbroser/rune app to control the dnla renderer/airplay/local media player.

Of course you can use any Linux version that works with the Raspberry Pi Zero W.

Soldering experience for small parts needed, experience with the Raspberry (flash sd card, setting up, config adjustments).

Look at http://www.runeaudio.com/forum/raspberry-pi-zero-support-in-0-4-t3711.html for RuneAudio and Raspberry Pi Zero.

Technical specification:

Size: 82mm x 60mm x 11mm
Weight: 55 gr
Battery: 1600ma
Boot time: ~30 sec
Runtime streaming: ~6 hours

needed Hardware:

1 micro usb cable - 2 usd
1 Raspberry Pi Zero W board - 10 usd
1 18650 powerbank - 2 usd
1 polymere lithium ion battery (max size 76mm x 27mm x 8mm) - 6 usd
1 Powerswitch - 1 usd
1 16gb/xx gb fast micro sd card with rune audio image - 8 usd - xx usd

Install the RuneAudio OS on the microsd card and test the installation, use a wall adapter and a mirco usb cable. If everything is fine expand the rune os partition to use the full space of your micro sd card (https://raspberry-hosting.com/en/faq/how-expand-arch-linux-root-partition). Use sftp to the /mnt/MPD/LocalStorage folder to transver your music files.

Print the case, test if the two case parts fits well, some afterwork may be needed (depends of the print quality). If everything fine glue the window in with superglue.

Remove the powerbank board and desolder the big usb connector and the two battery connectors. Solder two cable to the powerbank pcb - place of the big usb connector, pin 1 (positiv - orange cable) and 4 (ground/negativ - white cable) (power out to the Raspberry Pi Zero W), secure them with 2 component glue.

(Read this first and test the placment befor using the glue) - Take the Raspberry Pi Zero W and place it in the down case, should secure fit via the two micro usb ports cut outs. Use a small amount of 2 component glue and put a small ammount on the top of the camera connector. Now you take the powerbank pcb, put some glue on the ferrit part and place it so that it fit the charging micro sub cut of the case, use 2 clothes pegs, wait till the glue is cured. When the placment was right and fits well use hot glue between the Raspberry Pi Zero W and the powerbak board for a secure fit. You can now solder the two cabels to the Raspberry Pi Zero W board (google serach "raspberry pi zero pinout"), using a longer positiv cable and cut them later for connecting the power switch.

Take the Raspberry Pi Zero out and solder the micro usb cable to the underneath of the Raspberry Pi Zero W board, use the golden test points (test the lengt of the cable first). Secure the cabels with 2 component glue.

Solder the powerswitch to the positiv cable.

Solder the battery to the powerbank board and test your work, everything should work now.

Secure the powerswitch in the case with 2 component glue (only underneath). Put the battery, Raspberry Pi Zero W in the case and test if the case can be closed, if it's fine, secure the Raspberry Pi Zero W board with 4 drops hot glue in the case (so you can remove it easy if needed). Secure the micro usb cable with some hot glue. You can secure the battery with adhesive tape but it's not needed (depends on the battery size).

Close the case using superglue.

If you want to use the case for other projects/dacs, don't solder the micro usb cabel to the board, instead open the mirco usb out and/or hdmi port with a rasp, you see the size markin inside the case. Don't open the micro usb power port, you can only use this port if the power switch is off or (better) the battery is secured with a additional diode, DANGER OF FIRE DUE BATTERY OVERLOAD.

author: rumina

description.text:
This is my entry into the Makezine April Fools 3D Printing Contest (https://community.makezine.com/share/contests/april-fools)

The mug is designed with a ring of holes throughout the top of the mug. If someone tries to drink from the mug, the liquid inside will spill through the holes around the edge and rim of the mug.

The best part is only the person who created the STL file knows the secret! Download the 3D printable file and print your own. For best results, print at 100% infill. The secret trick in the mug is hidden at the 12 O'Clock position, but can be easily changed with Customizer or by editing the OpenSCAD file.

The Secret Trick: There is a hollow tube running through the mug's handle all the way through to the center of the inside of the mug. However, the same tube is connected to the customizeable secret trick tube. In order to drink from this mug, you'll need to use your fingers to cover the three holes at the 12 O'Clock position and then sip through the hole at the top of the mug above the handle. (If you try to sip through the handle/straw without covering the secret trick tubes, you'll just end up sucking air)

Go to " http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=2282587 " and customize the mug to design a mug of your own. When you open the file in Customizer, you can choose one of 11 different positions for the secret trick.

title: Spool Holder for Adafruit Copper Foil Tape #1128

description.text: I bought a roll of 1/4"/6mm copper tape from Adafruit. The problem was that in trying to use it, the tape had a tendency to turn into a large-scale copper Brillo(R) pad. A mess. So I designed a holder for the tape to keep this from happening. The two parts thread together with a 3D-printed thread. Adding a bit of lubricant to the threads helps them move smoothly. I applied a tiny dollop of Vaseline(R) petroleum jelly. The parts may be screwed together with various tightness; at its tightest, the roll of copper will not move at all; careful loosening of the parts will allow achieving an ideal looseness.

The part which threads into the holder to retain the roll The holder, as designed in AutoDesk Inventor The assembly, viewed as Creating screw threads

The "Thread" option of Inventor creates a picture of threads, but not actual 3D-printable threads. I posted a question in the Inventor forum at Autodesk, and was pointed to a tutorial on thread production. To make sure the threads fit properly (they didn't, on my first attempt) I created an assembly, set the view to "Wireframe with Hidden Edges" and slid the two components together and made sure the parts had sufficient clearance.

description.text:
A cheap brushless drive conversion for non-insectweight robots. Cheaper than the standard P60 setup, but powerful nonetheless. Included are STLs for direct printing as well as IPTs for modifying to fit your needs. Feel free to modify them to suit your setup.

Printed with a 0.4mm nozzle out of Alloy 910. Layer height 0.11, extrusion size 0.4, feed multiplier 1.03, 4 top and bottom layers, 4 shells, 65% honeycomb infill, speed 1100 mm/minute.

Other Things Needed:
Harbor Freight 18V Cordless Drill (one per gearbox, all metal gears suggested)
*either pull the pinion off the 550 motor, or find a donor gear from another HF gearbox as the primary gears are the same size as the pinions.

Turnigy 2826-6 2300 kV Outrunner:
https://hobbyking.com/en_us/d2826-6-2200kv-outrunner-motor.html?___store=en_us

TY-P1 ESC (has to be flashed with SimonK bootloader the hard way first time around):
https://hobbyking.com/en_us/turnigy-ty-p1-25amp-hexfet-brushless-speed-controller.html?___store=en_us

12mm ID bearing (of your choice, the one used was found on eBay)

This is a Cigarette Rolling Machine which can be used to roll cigarettes up to 90mm.
Cut and add a "belt", i would recommend one of those plastic bottle labels which you can find on nearly every PET-bottle.But you can also use other things, be creative.The belt needs to be 90mm long and X mm wide. The wider you make the belt, the thicker your cigarettes will be. You should figure that out on your own. You may want to look up how these rolling machines work. I have created a longer one for longpapers and made the rolls conical, if you want to roll a conic cigarette. If you're interested look at the remixes. The picture shows an older version. But it's nicer to see stuff before you print it, right?

A 3D print of a bofors gun, cannot recall where I found it cannot be sure it even prints

The file "Bofors with jacks lowered" is at approx 1/100 for Flames of war etc. The original model is standing very high on the adjusting jacks I have lowered this which ought to help it print better.

Bofors lowered beefed is a more robust model with a separate thicker barrel

If the barrel breaks here is the way I made a barrrel for the model in the pics

My solution (takes a couple of goes to get right)

Take some 1.5 dia (unshrunk) heat shrink sleeving (4 feet for about $2)
Find a piece of rod approx. same dia as broken off stub of gun (eg. darning needle)
Slide a 1" length of heatshrink about 1/8" inch over the rod
shrink down with a heat gun or powerful hairdrier.
While still floppy pull the heatshrink straight
then slide out the short section of rod
you now have a gun barrel which flairs out at one end to slide over the gun stub
fix in place with superglue
trim to length
resulting gun barrel is very tough and will take acrylic paint.

title: HICTOP i3 Motherboard to MKS GEN V1.4 Mounting Adapter

description.text:
My Extruder stopped working on my HICTOP i3. Being as the Stepper drivers are Integrated on the motherboard I decided to use a MKS Gen V1.4 with replaceable stepper drives instead. The mount did not accommodate the MKS Gen V1.4 board so I made an adapter. The standoffs on the adapter required you to tap the holes with an M3 0.5 tap so you can screw down the new board to the adapter once you have mounted it to the fixture mount that came with the printer.

The stepper directions between boards are reversed so I included modified versions of a newer version of Marlin (Marlin 1.1.0-RC6) (Downloaded from Here:https://github.com/MarlinFirmware/Marlin) that will work with the HICTOP i3. This newer version does not have the same lag in the SDCARD menu like included with the stock Marlin firmware included with the HICTOP i3. I have uploaded a copy of the Marlin firmware in Single (Hictopi3-Single_Extrusion), and Dual extrusion (Hictopi3-Dual_Extrusion) versions in the event you do not have experience with the code. I have also included Arduino IDE 1.6.1 (arduino-1.6.1-windows.exe) (Downloaded from Here: https://www.arduino.cc/en/Main/OldSoftwareReleases#previous) which you will need to upload your selected code version to your Motherboard.

1.) Plug your USB cable from your computer to your motherboard. (You can do this without connecting power to the motherboard)

2.) From the Tool menu -> Board -> Select "Arduino Mega or Mega 2560"

3.) From the Tool menu -> Processor-> Select "ATmega2560 (Mega 2560)"

4.) From the Tool menu -> Port-> Select (Select ComPort your Motherboard is addressed to IE: Com3)

5.) To Compile and upload: Click on the Arrow with a circle around it pointing right. It is next to the right of the Check with a circle around it located under the file menu. Progress Bar will be in the lower right of the IDE. When it is done it will let you know as the Progress Bar will disappear and in the black area below the code (Immediate window) It will tell you it is done.

If you decided to use the Dual Extrusion code you will need to setup your offset between your nozzles in millimeters. This can be found on lines 139 and 140 in the Configuration.h.

X Offset: #define EXTRUDER_OFFSET_X {0.0, 5.0} // (in mm) for each extruder, offset of the hotend on the X axis
Y Offset: #define EXTRUDER_OFFSET_Y {0.0, 0} // (in mm) for each extruder, offset of the hotend on the Y axis

Your Y offset will likely be 0 as your second extruder is likely to the right of you first extruder. Your You X is likely the only number you will need to change represented by the number 5.0 above. Measure with calipers from the center of you left extruder nozzle to the center of the right extruder nozzle. This number will be you offset in X.

In addition; the Rotary Encoder/Display Knob will rotate in reverse, if this bothers you, you can change it on line 866 of the Configuration.h file. Just remove the two forward slashes before the hashtag.

Just uncomment this://#define REVERSE_MENU_DIRECTION
Like this: #define REVERSE_MENU_DIRECTION

Another option is to just buy this $8 version here and you will not have any direction issues: https://folgertech.com/products/reprap-ramps1-4-2004-lcd-display-controller-with-adapter-mendel-prusa-3d-printer-1

You can buy the MKS Gen V1.4 here and it comes with the drivers:
https://folgertech.com/products/3d-printer-controller-ramps-1-4-for-reprap-mendel-prusa-arduino

Feel free to message me with any questions.

title: Triforce Fidget Spinner
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
At the request of a number of Thingiverse members, this 'Triforce' spinner is very similar to my previous 'Fidget Spinner' design at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2237509. It features designed in bearings and is a one piece print that should be almost ready to spin and fidget with straight off the build plate.

Fidget Spinners are a popular toy all around the world... this design provides the same ability to 'fidget' as any other 'Fidget spinner' however it is a one-piece-print with no metal bearings required. It should be almost ready to spin straight off the build plate!

The design features four designed in bearings. With a well sliced file printed on an accurate / precise machine the bearings should be free or take very little effort to break free straight off the build plate. As soon as the bearings have been freed add a small amount of lubricant to the moving bearing surfaces (refer images) and you're in business... ready to give your 'Fidget Spinner' a good spin. Is it as good as a spinner with metal bearings... probably not but they should still spin very well and are definitely fun to fidget with!

You can spin your Triforce Fidget Spinner in several ways... a smooth running spinner can be spun in just one hand by holding it in the centre then flicking one of the arms from the top or bottom... or you can get a faster spin by hitting one of the arms with a finger on you other hand. As there are four bearings designed in you can also hold one of the outer bearings and flick the spinner around using them instead of the centre bearing (refer images)

TIP: Once all four bearings have been freed apply a good spray of silicon spray or other light lubricant into the grooves between the main body and bearing on both sides of the spinner. Silicone is an amazing lubricant and a simple way to make 3D printed surfaces move really well against each other.

WARNING: To achieve a great result printing this design you need a good slicing app and accurate / precise machine due to the fine clearances applied. Although the clearances used should work satisfactorily with most slicing apps and machines others may find it a challenge and fuse the parts together. Usually fused parts can be freed however the alternative is to uniformly scale the design up by 5% which will increase the internal clearances.

'TIGHT' Version: A 'tight' file version has been added for members who have really accurate / precise / well set up machines able to print to very fine tolerances. This reduces the bearing clearance by approx. 0.1mm. On accurate / precise machines this will ensure the bearings are not too loose and rattle when spun. They should run smoothly and give a superior spin if well lubricated. An accurate / precise machine and slicing apps is essential to get a good result.

This is an easy print of a fun gadget but does require an accurate / precise slicing app and machine to achieve the necessary clearance between the moving parts so it will spin well and freely. Applying the lubricant is also essential to getting a really good spin and being able to spin it with just one hand (Metal bearings require lubrication too so this just requires the same).

Retaining the standard scale is recommended to maintain the designed in clearances and also ensure sufficient space between your thumb and forefinger for it to spin. However, you can get creative with colours by pausing your machine multiple times mid-print and changing filament... print in your favourite color or color combination to make your own unique spinner.

Triforce Fidget Spinner' also make great gifts as well... and with this design you don't need to buy any expensive metal bearings to achieve a similar result. Will a spinner with metal bearings spin better or longer... probably due to the added weight but this does a pretty good job at much lower cost and it's entirely 3D printed!

Have fun... and please post images of your Triforce Fidget spinners in use for other members to see.

Please refer to the print settings / instructions and images for additional information. Higher than usual shells and infill is recommended as this adds weight which will help your spinner maintain momentum.

Note: If you like this check out the rest of my fun and practical designs.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator+

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Standard / 0.20mm

Infill:

PLA / 2 shells / 50% or more infill

Notes:

Use high infill to add weight. No support but raft is recommended for ease of removal from the build plate.

Add lubricant

Make sure your spinners bearing are free of excess filament. They should spin (almost) straight off the build plate. Usually just a fraction of sideways pressure will free the bearing. Once free spray in / dribble in a small amount of a light lubricant to help ensure your spinner spins really well.

Spinners free up during use. Use it a lot and it will free up further and spin longer and faster.

title: Minimalist Cetus Z Axis Brace - No Disassembly Required
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Cures Z-wobble like the original by Steamkraft. Designed from scratch, but serves the same function. Did not fancy disassembling the printer or using so many screws, so used snap fits and tight tolerances where possible. Also uses the Cetus nozzle wrench as a stiffening member (doubles as a wrench holder!).

Caution: As part is designed to be a permanent addition, snap fits are tight and not easily removed. you'd have to either break the part or clear one end of the profile to slide the part out. Decide if this is for you & test fit on a separate profile (filament spool holder) if in doubt.

Parts Required:
1x m3 nut
1x m3x20 screw
1x Included nozzle wrench

Assembly:
1) Insert the m3 nut into the channel (might be a tight/loose fit depending on your dimensional accuracy. Shave some material off it it is too tight)
2) Pre-thread the screw into the nut to snug it into the channel and keep it aligned. Remove screw.
3) Attach wrench
4) Position part at correct height and snap into profile (will take some force).
5) Secure screw from bottom of base plate (see pictures). Done! Easy Peasy

See http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2284615 to store your nozzles on the printer.

Printer:

Cetus3D

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

In correct orientation, prints with no supports required. Fast setting in Cetus Studio. Part's CG is close to centre of footprint but raft recommended to help stability due to high aspect ratio as the Cetus build plate moves.

Tested with both PLA and ABS on Cetus (unheated build plate).

title: OpenRC F1 2017 Front Suspension - flexible filament

description.text:
This is a supension for the OpenRC F1 car with the 2017 updates.
It uses the same design as http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2069719 but in thruth it is modifications of Daniel Norée's 2017 update parts with the design and flex block from Drazen's suspension.

Video of the suspension: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=x9xCFjb56Qk

I printed the flexible parts with 35% infill and 2 shell layers.

To fit it, I used a long screw (M3x30) with a few lock nuts to hold the servo connection, and using http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2118536 as the servo connection.

This has the disadvantage that you no longer have a servo saver (I bought a load of super cheap servos of hobby king to compensate).

I find that the steering in general tend to snap into a oversteer position, which hurts the servo, so I put longer screws (M3x20, but 15 would have been enough) in the servo push rods, to prevent it from happening (see picture).

description.text:
A while ago I bought some bearings from aliexpress. They were very cheap! A few weeks later I found out they are very very small. I decided to find a use for them. This is my take on the very popular fidget spinner.

Now also available for the common 608 Bearings (8x7x22mm).

For a better version of the spinner suitable for the 608 bearings check out Gkbeer's remix!

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1-0.2

Notes:

The axis are pretty hard to print, be sure to use a very low speed for these.
The axis are only 3mm in diameter. After printing you can use an xacto knife to chamfer the edges to make them fit. Use a tiny amount of super glue, to glue the axis to the tops.

For this project I used 6x 3x4x10mm bearings. Before using them I soked them in White gas for a while to remove the grease. Other solvents such as acentone, gasoline, white spirit etc will work just fine.

title: F type to N type BNC Converter

description.text:
FYI: This is really not public ready! But here I am anyway... first personal design/print.
The stl should be the size that worked reasonably well for me, but there was lots of ooze making the inner diameter small. I printed with a raft and did not remove it because it gave me closer to the height I needed.
This is my first design/print (maybe my 50th attempt at printing, ha! Glad to be joining the community finally though.
So, what is it? It's an F-Type female to N-Type female BNC converter. Radioshack didn't have any N type, and the local ham shop was closed. So, why not print it?
At this size on my machine the ooze (I think that's what it's called) makes the inner diameter small enough that the F-type BNC needs to be pushed in, and the metal threads tear out a pathway. The copper wire in the picture is to provide some electrical connection from the grounded shielding to the nuts to the wave guide - this is only really necessary if you need that ground connection. This is my first antenna build as well...

• Print the part - may require some experimentation I relied on the ooze of my print to create an overly tight fit.

  • Leave the raft on, it keeps it closer to flush with the brass of the BNC (like an N-Type).

  • Drill out the 4 mount holes (or however you need to do this) and remove the raft just in the center hole so the BNC fits through it.

  • Press/tap the threads of your BNC connector into the plastic for a tight/flush fit - careful don't over do it!

  • Mount to object of choice (coffee can waveguide pictured).

description.text:
The Eachine Aurora 100 is an awesome micro FPV drone sold by banggood. It's is fast and flies very well, but not without some problems.. The antenna being exposed is one and if you tilt it (like I did) it touches the carbon fiber of the frame - making the FPV signal poorer...

This is my attempt on a antenna protection for the Aurora 100 and probably a better reception of the FPV signal - because it prevents the antenna from touching the carbon fiber of the frame when tilted .

title: Remixed Anet A8 Power Supply Cover with Switch(es) and Plug

description.text:
Modified design of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1927894.

This power supply cover version is designed for three switches for serveral different LEDs or fans and power supply inlet plug for the Anet A8 S-240-12 PSU.

The cover is mounted with two screws on the left and ride side to the PSU.
Further, the design is less filament consuming by thining out thick blocks from original design.

Please make sure you are working safe with high voltage and double check all connections with patient.

Following parts are recommended

https://www.conrad.de/de/wippschalter-250-vac-6-a-1-x-ausein-sci-r13-66a-02-rastend-1-st-700851.html

https://www.conrad.de/de/kaltgeraete-steckverbinder-c14-serie-netzsteckverbinder-59jr-stecker-einbau-vertikal-gesamtpolzahl-2-pe-schwarz-k-b-1-st-708562.html

Have fun & stay safe!

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

30%

Notes:

The design is optimized for print it front side down.

Make sure there is enough adhesion between hot bed and the print to avoid bending.

I used following settings.
Extruder: 205° C
Hot bed: 40° C (Vertex Build Tak)
Print speed: 55 mm/s
Infill print speed: 65 mm/s
Fan: 70 %
Printing time ≈ 5,5 h

comments.text: I saw your original article posted somewhere else last year. Curious, I began to read more and your project became the core idea of my own version of your weather station. In mine, I not only use the BME280 for environmental data, but I also have a connection to OpenWeatherMap for collection of local information, such as wind speed and direction. I also added NTP for time. And instead of using a cloud sourced app for the phone, I created an HTTP page to display the data in text format. I also added MQTT to send the data to my Mac, where I run Telegraf, InfluxDB, and Grafana for graphs of battery voltage, temperature, pressure, humidity and dew point. I've gone so far as to create a version that uses LoRa instead of the Wemos mini D1. That version will let me place a node, collecting just temperature, pressure, humidity and battery voltage readings, out in my pasture. All of my nodes use MQTT, so I can use Grafana to visualize all of them. I'm circling back to your project now that I have a 3D printer, a Prusa I3. I like your case, a lot. Thanks ever so much for your inspiration!

description.text:
Hi!

This is my second arcade controller case.

If you love retrogaming this one will make you happy. I scaled by 3 the measurements of the classic SNES controller and the result is a huge and nice arcade controller.

Side buttons (L & R) works great, and the select+start buttons are a bit loose but works ok too.

I bought the controller kit from ebay )http://www.ebay.es/itm/252687032631 ). Includes a Sanwa JLF joystick, 9 buttons (28mms) ,two 17mm small buttons and the usb cable+board. There's a lot of kits from many sellers, just take care of the model of joystick and the buttons.
You may need 6 full buttons and the switches from other 2 buttons (used for select and start)

Biggest part is 184x169x70 mms so any standard 200x200 printer can manage well.

No supports needed Some parts have a sort of support that you can remove once printed,

Some instructions and tips:

Middle part has 3 variants: One with a hole for a 17mms button (used as hotkey in Recalbox/Retropie) and room for the usb cable. Second variant didn't have the hole for hotkey button but has abig 'door and room for the USB. The last one only has a hole and a cap for the usb cable. Better see the pictures and choose the better for you.

Easy to mount. The 3 parts of the case can be joined with M4 or M5 x 20 mms nut/bolts. Also you can print the 'pin15mms.stl', inserting in holes and use some kind of superglue (this works great)
The switches for select and start buttons fits with M3x25mms nut/bolt or just use a bit of glue or a zip-tie.

The top plates fits in the case just pressing carefully.

When mounting the side buttons, first put the base and use the 'sidebuttons_pin.stl' then once the button works, put the top part from outside pressing carefully, you can use some glue if the top part stays loose.

You may need some sanding if some parts didn't fit but i mounted all the thing without sandind.

A VERY IMPORTANT TIP for printing: Use 'horizontal expansion' with -0.1 int top plates, that's very important when inserting the 'select - start' letters and the grey plate for the buttons of the right side. This horizontal reduction can avoid lots of sanding. (In cura slicer it's called 'horizontal expansion' but i'm pretty sure that most of slicers includes this option)

Last, i've included the original 'Nintendo' logo and the 'Bigtendo' used for the pictures. This logo pieces has 2mms height and for printing well, you may need to change filament after the 1mm layer.

And you can make a big combo using the Raspberry NES case http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1887826

See the pictures below for details and mounting tips.

Some parts (the top plates) are designed in OpenSCAD and the case and side buttons are designed using 123DDesign. (files included, feel free to modify or remix)

Well that's a fast description and my english it's not as good as i would but i hope you can print and mount the whole thing wihtout major issues.

Hope you enjoy it
Have fun!

Printer:

BQ Prusa i3 Hephestos

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 for small parts, 0.25 or 0.3 for big parts

Infill:

20% it`s ok

Notes:

No supports!!!

Print the one you prefer. Side buttons parts Use 2 spacer and the ring for the side buttons Put in place and screw the nut put the base part use the pin to grip the piece Once the button it's like this, you can fit the top part pressing carefully. Maybe you'll need some sanding if didn't fit or some glue if stays loose Use horizontal expansion with -0.1 or -0.15 to ensure the grey part fits well. The buttons Insert the cross into white plate, use some glue if stays loose. Detail of the Start-select switches. Use M3 bolt or a zip tie Detail of the cable grip. It's strong. Playing Street Fighter in a 5'' screen with a half meter controller....just a funny picture

comments.text: hi..is it supposed to print standing up or laying down? i started print standing object up and during print it looked like some spaghetti like stuff was there and it did not look stable. i am new to the 3d world of printing.  help thanks
comments.author: Crvdude

comments.text: You should print it laying down. I included both files (flat and standing up). Think of it this way...if you are printing the standing version, you wold need the printed material to 'stick' to something (the build plate). In the standing design, the only surface touching the build plate is the very point of the heart, so you would need support setting enabled when sliced. If you just print the laying down version, no support is needed and you can just print. There is enough surface area on the laying down version for the material to 'stick' to the build plate. The surface area is the 'back' of the heart and back of the letters, if the item was facing you.

author: Harrymausi

title: Raspberry Pi Wall Mounted Case - Ideal for Pi-Hole

description.text:
Wall mountable case for a Raspberry Pi. Ideal for use with Pi-Hole or other network devices.

Please Note: Don't forget to adjust the regulator board to 5V BEFORE connecting the Raspberry Pi, these boards are shipped with the adjustment turned up high and will damage your Pi!

The reason I used a regulator board to power the Pi is that 12V wall adaptors are more common place than good 5V 2A ones, also I don't like the flimsy micro USB connectors. The current draw at @12V for this finished unit was around 130mA when using a B+, maybe a little more for a Pi 3.

comments.text: What size LED are you using? I can't get a 5MM LED in there and the hole is waaaaaayyyyy to big for a 3mm.
comments.author: ni2o

comments.text:
Hi
I've been using the LM2596 regulators modules for years with no issues. The chip is rated at 3A, far more than the Pi needs, the regulation and noise is low, low enough not to be an issue with the Pi.
I even have a Raspberry Pi web server using one of these modules that has been in continues use now since 2013, runs cool and stable. Also I've used these modules to power network cameras made using Raspberry Pi B's and home made power over Ethernet.
The only issues I have with these modules is that they are shipped with the output turned up hi, they do need to be set to 5V BEFORE connecting the raspberry Pi. The only other thing is that they don't have reverse polarity protection, that's easy to solve with either a 1 or 3A diode or a bridge rectifier.

Wall mount for boxes

This is, by far, not a fancy test bar as can be found here on thingiverse, but the main goal was not to create the bar itself, but the factory file for simplify 3D to automate the process.

The idea is to print a bar with a single outline (like in vase mode) and change the extruder temperature every 10 mm. After printing the bar gives some information on the best temperature setting for the given material/printer. Setting this up can take some time and this factory for S3D does just that.

The first layer is a custom process. This allows tweaking the first layer to get it to stick nicely on the platform. The other processes are defined for each 10 mm (and labeled as such). Of course they can be changed at will.

Because the 10 mm steps are in a group and the only difference is the extruder temperature, changing any other setting will apply to every process in the group. This makes it very easy if you want to see the result at different speeds for instance.

I designed the factory file for a Wanhao Duplicator i3 plus, but this can easily be changed if necessary.

print_settings.Notes:: I added a dab of superglue and was going to place a #8 washer on top to hold the nut in, but decided that may actually put too much stress and pop in out, so I just let the glue dry. So technically there is glue holding it in as well.

description.text:
I had a bad thumbscrew and while waiting for Tevo to send me a replacement, I modified Ulmenkott's design in tinkercad. I should have made the hole .5 mm larger. As it is, just line up a M3 nut, heat it and press down.

I used a soldering iron, but someone else said just screw the M3 on the tip of a M3 bolt, heat with a lighter and press it in. I used 2-3 #8 washers on top to give me space between the nut and the bottom of the bed holder, plus I have the aluminum bed holder, not acrylic. This was just an emergency fix for me.

title: Makerbot Bre Pettis Rod Puppet
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A basic rod style puppet to renact your favorite makerbot adventures. 
You have the choice of any head listed below.
I will update with completed picture soon.
There is room for improvement, what ideas do other people have?

Print each .stl file. Cut 2 pieces of 3/8" wooden dowel to be 6" long.
One dowel will be the handle, the other will be the control rod for the head.
Put one end of the handle in the hole in the torso that does NOT go all the way thru. Use some Hot Glue to hold it in place.
Sand a flat face on the top 2" of the head control rod
Print one of the head files. For Bre choose the "breclosed.stl". For Unfold's head choose "3smoreUpsDown.stl"
Hot glue the head to the control rod.
Put the Head control rod thru the torso.
Hot glue the other end of the control rod into the 'Head Handle'.
Hot glue a 1/4" dowel rod into the hole on each hand piece. Make some clothes for your puppet and you are good to go!

remixed_from.author: Cxquek
remixed_from.title: Barrier + Gate for 3 way dice tower

description.text:
This is a textured version of @cxquek's barrier for @bainite's 3 Path Dice Tower v2.

The fact that I named 2 other makers in the first sentence so be obvious - I didn't create anything here ;)

I used the same pattern from texturelib that @bainite used on his tower. My stones came out smaller though because of some scaling. Now that I figured out a relatively do-able workflow, I'll probably do another version that better matches.

A couple of notes:

  • I had a bear of a time adding depth. All the F360 info out there suggests using "Offset Faces", but it would error most of the time. I finally hit on getting it to work by trying to negative extrude the underlying face first, then using offset faces with a number less than the displayed radius OR "-1" (it varied).
  • This isn't primetime ready - there's a couple of spots where the intent didn't meet execution.

Mad props to both @bainite for his original inspiration and @Cxquek for taking the plunge to create the barrier. I printed the tower for a friend and had given some time and thought to a barrier at his request, but I didn't give enough of either to make any progress heehee.

Side note - I thought I had it beat using 3D Builder's "emboss" feature, but the stones would consistently have tops (outside faces) smaller than the base and angles created by the size diff, the mortar space was much to big for my liking, and the actual depth didn't seem to change.

I gave Meshmixer a run too - man, me and MM just do not speak the same language. I'm sure someone with some MM skills could do it, just not for me.

description.text:
This is a remix from the nice work made by Endogladry and inspired by Zapwizard:
http://www.zapwizard.com/blog/fallout-4-holotape-prop-version/

This model is printable in different parts so you won't need to paint it.

There is a hole for a 3mm standard LED, which I connected to 2 smalls buttons battery (1.5V each) but a classic 3V button battery (CR2025 or 3032) would work too.

I added a 56 ohms resistor inside and the LED is activated by pressing the grey button in the corner, which hides a button coming from an ARDUINO kit.

I added the Sketchup file too :)

If you don't have a 3D printer, I sell somes of this tapes on Etsy : http://etsy.me/2pgt8a3

print_settings.Notes:: I manage to fit 14 male ends on my print bed, and 6 female ends at a time. The first layer can be a bit tricky (especially on the hole variants of the female ends, feel free to fill them in if you need, or contact me and I can upload those).

description.text:
Pictures posted are a previous revision of this design. The revised design includes the tops closed off to prevent stronger magnets from colliding. Print the Male ends facing down, and the female ones facing up.

These fit 20mm neodymium magnets up to 5mm in thickness. You gotta buy these.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

100 microns

Infill:

N/A? 10% maybe

Notes:

Print Male ends facing down, and female can be printed facing up (so the whole is down the bottom).

This is due to a cone shape in the design, and should come out fine in both the 3mm and 5mm variants.

I manage to fit 14 male ends on my print bed, and 6 female ends at a time. The first layer can be a bit tricky (especially on the hole variants of the female ends, feel free to fill them in if you need, or contact me and I can upload those).

BUYING THE RIGHT MAGNETS!

I recommend using at least 3mm thick 20mm diameter neodymium magnets. In my set we used 3mm in the feetpaws, then 3mm in the toes but a 5mm thick in the heel. I have included thicker female ends for those of you who use thicker foam.

Adhesion.

Use a blob of hot glue, superglue or 2 part epoxy to secure each magnet into the holder, making sure to note they all have the correct facing polarities.

I use 2 part clear epoxy on the male ends and simply press them into the foam until they stick.

Female ends will require you to cut holes for the magnets to line up in. I used a circular drill piece and just fumbled with it by hand. The little teeth will grab onto the foam, glue this in how you like, super glue, hot glue and epoxy is fine. Having backing foam is a big help.

Optional: You can screw these suckers in if you like. This could also help retrofit existing outdoor feet by making small holes and epoxying the screws and female ends in place. Haven't done it but the epoxy is quite strong.

24v 300w heated bed 400x200, for 3drag big.
Use the aluminum plate supplied with the 3drag,
degrease and cover the lower part with the kapton tape
Take 2 pieces of about 3 meters of 0.5 mm steel wire in diameter, check that 3 meters give 4 ohm resistance.
Place the wire with ribbon pieces and create a serpentine.
Cover all the coil with abundant silicone or temperature resistant polyurethane sealant.
Connect the two coils in parallel at 24V (2x4ohm in parallel=2ohm @ 24V = 288w).
Easily reaches 100 degrees in just a few minutes!!!

author: techedwalt

description.text:
This is universal hexbit holder that can be mounted to a wall.
It can hold 20 long bits and it takes less than 40 grams of filament to print it. I wanted bits to stick in tight, but at the same time they should be easily taken out. Such affect is achieved by 2 circles inside the hex hole. I have learned that different bits have different diameters, but I wanted this holder to be universal. So I did a lot of testing before coming to this exact size.
Also holes have no button, so support is not necessary and as a bonus dirt doesn't stay in them.
Take a look at the description picture, to see all design specials.

I recommend to print it upside down, this way you will not need support. I personally use nylon for printing such kind of stuff, but guess any filament will work.

Since it was designed with Tinkercad you can edit it online, so that it fits your needs. https://www.tinkercad.com/things/06HHHlNXb0Z

This is a new version/design of a simple quadruped robot. The robot should be easy to print on a hobby grade printer (the one depicted was print on a Prusa I3Mark2). The assembly doesn't requires screws/bolts , the parts click-fit together (0.3mm of tolerance).

For the electronics you will need 8 servos (9G.) a microcontroller a servo controller and power. The model in the picture use the following:

Ada fruit Feather (https://www.adafruit.com/products/2829)
Adafruit 8 channel Servo FeatherWing (https://www.adafruit.com/products/2928)
4xAA Batteri holder (https://www.adafruit.com/products/830)
8x MG90S High Speed Micro Servo Metal Gear
The robot was designed using OnShape, a browser based parametric CAD software package. You are free to copy/customise the project. The link to the project is: https://cad.onshape.com/documents/0accd1a24676e15bf99fd11e/w/0962067c20c6b1476c426a1c/e/33ba89d76935e0f2094cbde6

You can read more about other quadruped bots at my blog at www.burningservos.com and on twitter @ronaldxjt.

I'll add a link here to an Instructable I'm currently working on.

title: Mirrored Closet Door Top Slider Repair

description.text:
The top slider on my mirrored closet door was a cheap plastic part, and over time it had cracked and failed.

Home improvement stores did not stock this style of slider, and the remaining parts looked like they were about to crack as well. It was another perfect opportunity for 3d printing to save the day again.

I drew this up in Fusion 360 - but for some reason, I can't find the STEP file - but I was happy with the result, so if your sliders look like this - this part should fit, and be an improvement in strength.

A cheap pop rivet, fixed it securely to the metal mount, and it's been in place and working great ever since.

A customizable sanding block designed to economize by not requiring much extra length of sandpaper to wrap around and clamp in place. Default dimensions are small, but you can make it whatever size you like. You can also customize the end angles. The clamping pieces are printed inside, in close enough proximity that they don't tip over during printing, and probably stick lightly to the inside of the block. I was able to pry them off easily with a screwdriver afterwards.

Vitamins required: 2 M5 bolts (around 1.5-2cm long) and 2 M5 square nuts. Wing bolts might be nice if you have them, otherwise you'll need a screwdriver to install the sandpaper. Or use hex-head bolts and print out a pair of knurled knobs. If you want to make a soft pad on the bottom, you can use some self-adhesive felt or cork, or glue on a piece of denim from old jeans.

Mavic Pro ULTRA

Lande-System inkl. Wasserlande-System

Stückliste:

1x Landerahmen
4x Beine
4x Eckabdeckung
4x Wassernudel Frontabdeckungen
8x Abdeckungen seitlich für Eckabdeckungen
8x Abschlusszapfen (für Carbon-Stangen)
4x Abschlusszapfen gross für Schwimmer.
2x Augen/Front
2x Carbon-Stangen 6mm / Innendurchmesser: 4mm Längsträger: 185mm
2x Carbon-Stangen 6mm / Innendurchmesser: 4mm Querträger: 250mm
Schwimmnudel Durchmesser 62mm
2x Styroporkugel Durchmesser: 70mm (massiv) Bohrung 5mm
4x Beinabstandhülsen zu WN
2x Abstandhülsen für Schlüssel
2x Seiten-Abdeckungen für Schlüssel/WN
2x Schlusslicht-Abschlusszapfen für Schlüssel
Abdtand-Lehre für Beine: nur Lehre NICHT verleimen!
Leim Typ: Loctite 401

Wichtiges zur Montage:

Die Carbon-Stangen müssen klemmen und nicht lose sein. Die Abschlusszapfen an den Querträger werden nicht verleimt, somit ist ein einfaches Auffädeln der vier Styropor-Kugeln/Schwimmnudeln möglich. Also Abschlusszapfen weg Kugel/Wassernudel mit 5mm Loch auffädeln und Abschlusszapfen wieder montieren und fertig ist das Wasserlande-System. Die vier Beine hingegen werden fest mit dem ULTRA-Rahmen verleimt, verwende Loctite 401 der hält sehr gut.
Ebenfalls die vier Eckabdeckungen werden verleimt.
Wenn Ihr ohne Styropor Kugel oder Wassernudeln fliegt könnt Ihr das Carbon-Gestänge nach belieben verschieben. Sonst wäre der Frontabstand 20mm damit das Gestänge nicht mitgefilmt wird. Ich selbst fliege fast immer mit den Wassernudeln auch auf Land da eine gedämpfte Landung immer gewährleistet ist. Wasserlandungen sind mit den Wassernudeln ebenfalls die bessere Wahl, Gewicht ist dasselbe wie Styroporkugeln. Und die Wasserlandung ist auch weicher. Noch ein Wichtiger Hinweis: kommt nicht auf die Idee eine dritte Wassernudel in der Mitte zu Montieren, sonst deckt ihr die Sensoren des Mavic Pro zu!
Das komplette ULTRA so wie wir es fliegen inklusive Wassernudeln hat ein Gewicht von nur 150 Gramm und ist total auf Stabilität getestet.

Druck-Tipps :

ULTRA Landerahmen muss mit Stützstruktur gedruckt werden, wegen Einrasthaken und Klick-System der Beine.
Druckgeschwindigkeit: 50%
Wärmeplatte: 42 C
Innofil PLA 2.85
Temperatur Düse: 210 C

Meine Flugerfahrung mit dem ULTRA:

Kein Umknicken bei der Landung möglich, es ist fast oder ist wie ein Trainingsgestell. Wenn Du also noch nie mit deiner Mavic Pro geflogen bist, empfehle ich dir wärmstens mit dem ULTRA zu fliegen.
Keine Flugstörungen sprich Signalverluste, weil die Original Vorderbeine des Mavic Pro die Antennen sind. Wir haben eine Messung gemacht mit Überbeinen, und mussten tatsächlich einen Signal-Verlust hinnehmen. Daher rate ich jedem Mavic Pro Piloten auf Überbeine zu verzichten (Antennen müssen frei sein nicht bedeckt, versteht sich)
Perfekte Wasserlandungen mit dem ULTRA sind kein Problem und die Wassernudeln oder Styropor-Kugeln sind schnell montiert.
Verbesserte Kameraführung vom Start weg da die Mavic Pro jetzt auf über 10cm Bodenfreiheit verfügt.
Es macht einfach einen riesigen Spass mit dem Ultra zu fliegen. Schenk deinem Mavic Pro ein richtiges Landesystem.

Wünsche jedem Mavic Pro Piloten viel Erfolg mit dem ULTRA.

Danke für ein „like“ denn wir sind für FAIRPLAY.
Merci...THX

Video wird noch folgen.

ULTRA ist Registriert und darf nicht zum Verkauf angeboten werden!Jedoch gratis/frei Downloadbar auf thingiverse.com.

NEWS und UPDATES:
02.05.2017 - 4 x Abstandhülsen von Beinen zu Wassernudel (damit die WN nicht rutschen auf dem Carbonstab, also fix sind. Wir werden die Updates hier immer publizieren, also reinschauen lohnt sich bestimmt.

03.05.2017 - Sehr Wichtiges Update:
Nach längeren Flugzeit und viel Spass auf und neben dem Wasser haben wir hier noch sehr wichtige Abänderungen anzubringen:

  • die Mittelstreben Carbonstangen müssen weg gesägt werden, damit die Sensoren richtig Arbeiten können. Nach unten muss der Weg also frei sein der Mavic Pro. Somit ist ein reibungsloser Flug sicher garantiert. Länge der vier Carbonstangen : je 100mm.
  • neu können ab sofort alle Carbonstangen verleimt werden, siehe Bilder.
    -ganz NEU ist ebenfalls der Schlüssel zum ULTRA. Schlüssel ? Ja es gibt einen Schlüssel, es ist die dritte Wassernudel hinten am ULTRA. Der Schlüssel ist 110mm lang und wie die anderen Wassernudeln im Durchmesser auch 62mm. Warum sprechen wir von Schlüssel? Es ist ganz einfach, der Schlüssel hält das ganze ULTRA System zusammen, die Spreizung kann sich also nicht lösen. Gleichzeitig dämpft der Schlüssel die Wasserlandung perfekt ab, da dieser etwas höher liegt als die anderen WN am ULTRA.Ganz ehrlich gesagt wir haben heute nur mit ULTRA geflogen, egal ob Wasserlandung oder Bodenlandung. Es macht extrem Spass so zu fliegen, und gibt sehr viel mehr an Sicherheit beim fliegen.
    -neu sind auch die Abstandsbegrenzung zum Schlüssel.
  • am Schlüssel hinten haben wir noch zwei Abschlusszapfen montiert die aussehen wie ein Schlusslicht, sieht im Flug richtig gut aus. (Könnt Ihr natürlich gestalten wie Ihr es gerne möcht.
  • Nach dem Update ist das ULTRA ganze 180g leicht, was den Mavic Pro sicher nichts anhaben kann.

Wir haben heute 5 Stunden Flug mit dem Mavic Pro ULTRA verbracht und sind sehr zufrieden mit dem neuen Update, was aber nicht heisst das es keine Updates mehr gibt.

Wir sind immer am verbessern und geben das Beste, dass wir die Mavic Pro ULTRA Piloten glücklich machen können. Guten und sicheren Flug wünscht Dir Innofil.

I sometimes do voice-overs in iMovie and need a more directional mic. This thing easily snaps on the top of an iMac and makes the internal mic more directional. I got this idea from pblanton who needs this for Skype.

This was designed for a mid 2010 27" iMac, I don't know if Apple changed the dimension between the cooling slot and the top of the screen on other machines. On this machine it measures roughly 10mm from the top of the cooling slot to the top of the screen, then roughly 28mm across the top.
All parts were printed on a TOM with a MK6+. My settings were: Object infill% 35, Layer height(mm) .32, Number of shells 0, feedrate (mm/s) 32, RAFT and FULL support.
I requested RepG's Print-O-Matic to add a necessary raft and full support, for some reason it gave me a very sparse support structure and the print turned out rough, but still functional. Any help with this problem would be appreciated. 
Print the part. Clean up any sharp edges with sandpaper. Place the deflector front down first then push down until the rear tab snaps into rear cooling slot. To remove, just lift the front first and it pops off.

The case for my dial Caliper was breaking and getting in the way of other tools in my box. I decided to make this replacement case.

Little did I know that this project was beyond the current limits of my printer. I have a Geeetech Prusa I3 Pro C dual extruder printer. While the dual extruder is nice, it tends to limit the X travel. I had to modify my printer to get a few more mm movement out of it. Even at that, the slicer I use for some reason also limits the placement of the print.
Currently, after the modifications, I get about 180 mm in X and 198mm in Y direction with a 'single' extruder running. Yes, both extruders don't go to the very end of the glass plate in the x motion.

This usually hasn't been a problem until I try to print something that is 212 mm in length like this case!
So to print this, I had to place the item at an angle. But as this is at the limit of my printer, changes of 1/2 degree in placement made the difference of the print fitting on the bed or not!

I don't expect many to be able to use these files as it fits exactly my General Dial Caliper that I purchased years ago. I don't know if newer version will fit the same case.

Fusion 360

Designed in Fusion 360. Took a picture, imported into 360, scaled to size and then tweeked until it was perfect.

I've added files for the cover text that you can use. I wasn't able to print it again as I was having some problems with 'sticking'. I finally gave up trying to print with text as the shape really shows what is inside the case.

Update 4/30/17 add test size file. Since so many are collecting this for print I have added this file to test if your caliper will fit. It is just the outside edge of the 'box' so you can see if it will fit on your printer and if the caliper will fit. Hope this helps.

author: Splivi

description.text:
She's making spinner caps. He's making spinner caps. Well I haven't noticed this kind before so I'm posting it.
My cap interleaves the post to help lock it into place inside the 608 bearing.

I print this with 0 bottoms, 4 tops, and a 30% hexagonal (honeycomb) infill. This allows the hexagonal texture to come through the pad. It's easier on my fingers.

UPDATE: 5/6/17 - Someone broke the pins on one of their caps. So I thickened them up and added a little more material to them.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

30%
Insert the first cap all the way into the 608 bearing. Then use a little twist to line up the other side.

comments.text: I printed it but I can't get them to fit together and they are larger than the bearing too.
comments.author: MacGyver

comments.text: That's very strange.  They work perfectly in my 608 bearings.  You're not changing the scale?
comments.author: MacGyver

comments.text: Didn't change the scale at all.  The spinner I tried to fit them in is a standard 608 bearing the diameter of this thing is larger than the bearing so if you try to use more than one it hits the other caps you've got in place.  I'm talking about the total outside diameter of your thing which is 28mm+ the 608 bearing is only 22mm so there is quite a bit of overlap.

comments.text: Ah, I see what you mean.

Hi, I'm introducing you Foldy, a foldable delta 3D Printer!
Since I'm touring around working as a show technician, I needed a portable 3d printer, but since i like deltas, I've designed this wonderful foldable 3d printer!

It's some month ago I started taking this printer around inside a Stanley Tool Box like this: https://www.amazon.it/gp/product/B002V4SS3Y/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o07_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1
and also if I was worried it didn't last a lot, it's still alive and working!
I'm sorry, due to lack of time, I still don't have a good video to post, but I'll do it soon.

I can setup the printer in 5 minutes, it's just a mean of unfold and let the auto-locks set, screw 3 bolts on the heatedbed and plug the heatedbed, the LCD and the power switch.
It doesn't have an autocalibrate switch, but i'll add it, as soon as I can.
The mainboard is a normal ramps1.4 with repetierFW, but I like mk4duo... have to upload..
In the drawings there's no end effector, because I adapted what I had. As soon as I draw a better one, i'll put here too. it is working with a flying extruder, which can remain set when folding. I can also print flex filaments with that!

If someone want to make it, or to modify it, please let me know what comes out!

More pics to come..

comments.text: Great idea, I would love to remix and try to make a taller printer, with motors on top and extendable 2020 profiles. If you're interested in my idea let's get in touch!
comments.author: mmind

comments.text:
Hi, I think that due to the poor rigidity of the design, motors on the top will make the printer shake more.
Making it taller will be simple.
Sketchup can export in 3ds or Obj format. Since i run it in linux i cannot install stl export, so it's more complicated for me to give you stl. You can export in 3ds and than convert using repetier host or meshlab.
Let me know what comes out.
comments.author: mmind

comments.text: Thanks for your interest! Forgot to say you have to find 12 suitable springs for the locks. I cut them from a longer one, 8mm diameter, but till 6mm diameter i think will do the job. Or you can put there anything elastic.

comments.text: Wow I love it, been looking for something to travel but I love deltas!!, I will message when I start it!

2 - 8mm Nuts
1 - 8mm x 100mm Threaded Rod (Length can vary depending on size spools)

description.text:
This simple model is something you can make to test your 3D printers abilities. The first step in making this sphere inside a cube model, is to print the inside sphere model. After that has finished, clean it up with sand paper our some over form of smoothing, and set it aside. You should now change your plastic color for a better effect. Next start printing the outside cube, when you get halfway through the print, pause the printer and put the sphere in the half done cube. Finish the print and , voilà you now have a multi-colored sphere in a cube!

If you make this, please post a picture!

author: Renngarage

description.text:
Hi!

Sometimes i make weird things with Arduino boards.

A few weeks ago i make a Arduboy (for more info visit http://www.arduboy.com) clone with some buttons, screen, speaker and a Pro-micro soldering into a 70x50 mms piece of board.
The circuit is feeded with 2 little 3V bateries or by USB.

For any question about electronics and how to connect all the things please visit the Arduboy Community ( https://community.arduboy.com ). There's a lot of info and amazing people who develop games, software, hardware... and they are very pleased to help.

Once the Arduboy clone seems to work i designed this simple case.

There's two versions: One with a cross-hat for the direction buttons an other with 4 round buttons.

The back and top pieces are joined with two M2 screws (you can also use 2.5 screws)

The components i've used are:

  • Arduino Pro Micro
  • OLED 1.3''
  • Speaker
  • Potentiometer (control the volume of the speaker)
  • Switch buttons (recicled from broken mouses) but available at very low price in ebay or any electronics shop.

The cost of all electronis it's between 10-15€. Most of them buyed from China on ebay.

Also the Screen uses the Driver SSH1106 not compatible with the original Arduboy library but in the community it's easy to found a variation of the original library for different micros and screens.

Easy to print, no supports, no special configurations, just print, assemble with 2 screws and enjoy.

Designed in 123DDesign, i've included the original file, i encourage you to remix the design or modify for your needs.

Have fun!

description.text:
Mini Select V1 Glass Bed Clamp

As the only glass bed size available in my area is 210mm x 200mm x 3mm, I decided to made a glass bed clamp to hold the glass piece firmly.
It will be sufficient to just place it at the rear side while using normal clips to hold the front.
This is an extension of the 'mini G clamp' made by me earlier on at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2266210
Use PLA in all parts and print it in 100% ratio
Using glass bed is a tremendous improvement compare to stock mini or ordinary tape, which allow smooth and better 1st layer print, and an essential for ABS print as well.

Skid Protector x4, M2x16 screw x2, M2x8 screw x4, A2 nuts x8

description.text:
This is model of an "Eisstock", sports in bavaria, austria and switzerland.
Modeled in 1:2
Remix of the singer 201 bobbin. I added a flat spot so that it prints easier. This has the added benefit of keeping the bobbin from rolling around on your table.

• If you made this thing and are happy with it I kindly ask to give it a shout!

==================================================================
I like to use what is already there.
Thing is with that CTC that the arms are somewhat weak and instead adjusting the spring loaded heatbed the arms are bending somewhat....
Those stiffeners could be printed in decent time without buying
expensive machined aluminium parts.
What you need is the well known M3 nuts und decent long M3 screws (and shims if you like).
Place for the front one is obvious. It is up to you to add the writing in dual print or not.
Place for the big bar is exactly beneath both of the rectangular sectiones in the middle of the arms. For the holes there I attached a drill template.

Makes a big improvement, at least for me...

title: Pikachu Assembly Model Figure
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Pikachu Assembly Model Figure was made by using open software tools (FreeCAD and Inkscape). The result is a collection of multiple contour drawings, grouped together in a .dxf file and a .svg file. Both files can be cutter by a laser cutter.

The .dxf must be cutter on any material with a 3 mm thickness, no more, no less. I recommend MDF (Medium Density Fiberboard), although acrylic, cardboard, or plywood works too. But remember the 3 mm thickness constraint.

By other hand, the .svg file can be treated using a laser cutter as well. But first this should be printed over self-adhesive vinyl. Once we have the vinyl, we can proceed to cutter it using a laser cutter or a simple razor, blade or a box cutter.

At last, stick the vinyls on their respective mdf/plywood/acrylic part, and assembly. Now we're DONE!

Enjoy it :)

print_settings.Printer:: Wanhao Duplicator i3 Plus

description.text:
Ceiling Projection Clock / Night Light

The idea behind this was to create a nightlight/clock on the ceiling so that my children knew what time it was in the night – and stayed in bed!

The idea is to shine an LED through a ‘cut-out’ of the time (hours and minutes) and focus this onto the ceiling to show the time. As the time changes the ‘cut-out’ is moved to show the new time.
To do this I decided to have 2 wheels, one for hours and one for minutes. Each holds 12 ‘cut-outs’/stencils, one for each hour (1,2.. 11,12) and the other for each 5 minute interval (0,5…45,55). At night it is probably not necessary to know the time with better accuracy than 5 minutes. (For smaller children who can’t read numbers then these could be changed to suns, moons and other shapes!).

Since the resolution of a (my) 3D printer is not so great I decided to make the text approx. 1 cm high on a ¬20*20mm tile which could be slotted into each wheel.
To focus/image this onto a ceiling a lens is needed above the clock. The lens must be strong enough to form an image on the ceiling – initial tests with ‘cheap’ reading glasses showed that these were not strong enough. It should be noted that here there is a trade-off between strength of lens, magnification and LED brightness. If the focal length of the lens is short then it will need to be placed nearer to the clock – this in turn gives a larger magnification and means that LED may need to be brighter as the image is bigger, but also allows a smaller lens to be used as it is closer to the clock before the light has diverged so far. Conversely, a weaker lens would give a smaller image on the ceiling, it would need to be placed higher above the clock and would need to be bigger to capture the divergent rays. (If it is too weak then there will be no image – or at least it will be above the ceiling!)
I then found some creditcard sized Fresnel lenses which were pretty good. They need to be placed ¬15 cm above the clock before the beam is too divergent and form a 10ish cm high image on the ceiling. They do however need a reasonably bright LED – I found a 1000mcd LED was easily visible at night and 10000mcd visible in the day!

To drive the clock just one motor is used. A 28BYJ-48 stepper motor chosen as it is easily and cheaply available – the advantage of a stepper motor is that you know exactly how far it is going to rotate for a given number of steps. To keep the maths easy I decided to use a gear with 36 teeth for the large wheels. Since there 12 hours in the day and 12 five minute intervals in 1 hour then it must move 36/12 = 3 teeth at the time. The gear on the motor has 8 teeth, thus it must move 3/8s of a full turn for each 5 minutes. The gear box on my stepper motor had a gearing down of 1:64 – thus the number of steps could be calculated.
For the same reason the minute wheel has 3 teeth to drive the hour wheel forward by 1/12 of a revolution for each turn of the minute wheel.

To drive the stepper motor the small Arduino Nano (clone) was chosen which would fit inside the clock. The stepper motor comes with a driver board which can be directly connected to the Arduino.
Rather than use the stepper library, the motor can easily be tested/driven by sequentially pulsing the 4 pins high. I found that the minimum pulse duration of 2-3mS was needed for smooth movement – below this the motion was erratic.

To avoid potential damage to the Arduino/PC USB port you should disconnect any external power and the power connection between the Arduino and motor driver before (re)programming the device

Assembly
Once the parts are printed and cleaned up. Slot the hour and minute tiles into the Minute and Hour wheels. Make sure they are the correct way round or the projection may be inverted!, also on the minute wheel the ‘20’ tile should line up with the 3 teeth.
The Rings then fit over the tile pegs to hold the tiles in. It may be necessary to drill the holes in the ring and use glue to stop it falling off.
The Blinkers can also be fitted at this stage. These block stray light from the LEDs reaching the ceiling.
Extension wires should be soldered to the LEDs and the LEDs slotted in to the 2 LED holders.
The circuitry should follow the attached diagram.
The bolt holes may need to drilled out with a 6.5 mm drill.
Note the is also a small (4-5mm) spacer/washers between the 2 wheels
The motor gear should push tightly on the motor shaft.
The LED holders should be pushed in last as they block the wheels.
If the plates do not fit tightly then they can be glued.
The only other noteworthy thing is the yellow peg with a piece of grey filament sticking out in the photo. This pushes against the hour wheel to hold it in position and allow it to “click” from 1 hour to the next. If it is not fitted then the wheel can spin freely and show the wrong time. Another idea was to push the filament against the blinker to stop the wheel spinning, but this has not been tested.

Additional components
2x M6 90mm long bolts
Lens approx 15cm Focal length, wd 84 cm
Arduino Nano or similar
Super/Ultra bright LEDS (5mm, 1000-10000mcd)
Stepper motor 28BYJ-48
Mini 170 Tie Point Solderless Breadboard
5V PSU (I wouldn't recommend running it from a USB port)

Alterations...
The Base can be extended upwards to hide the electronics/wires etc… Similarly a lid could be made - I intend to try it soon - now uploaded, although it is a bit bulky.
I found it is probably possible to remove the high lens holder by using stronger watchmakers magnifier -two will be needed (one for each wheel) and they can be placed much lower down. It may be necessary to change the LED angles so the 2 numbers do not overlap on the ceiling.

(The original idea was to have a projection clock onto the ceiling and a shadow clock point horizontally through the clock. The wheels were drawn up with hour numbers and minute indicators
)

Motor Info:-
http://www.instructables.com/id/BYJ48-Stepper-Motor/
https://arduino-info.wikispaces.com/SmallSteppers
https://grahamwideman.wikispaces.com/Motors-+28BYJ-48+Stepper+motor+notes

To create the gears I downloaded and used Gears 3D Print (https://gears-3d-printer.en.softonic.com/ ). This creates STL files of the gears which can then be scaled up/down/editted in a CAD program.

http://www.instructables.com/id/Make-an-accurate-Arduino-clock-using-only-one-wire/

title: Post and Hole Fit Test
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I was learning OpenSCAD and wanted to know how much tolerance I'd need to build in to make models that needed to fit together with posts and holes, so I created this test.

This project uses a set of tiles to determine how much extra tolerance is needed in my OpenSCAD projects to fit circular parts together.

The tiles are split up into multiple files:

  • hole_tolerance_post.stl - The base tile with a post with radius set to 4mm.
  • hole_tolerance_TOL200u-to-280u - hole radii of sizes [4.20, 4.22, 4.24, 4.26, 4.28]
  • hole_tolerance_TOL300u-to-380u - hole radii of sizes [4.30, 4.32, 4.34, 4.36, 4.38]
  • hole_tolerance_TOL400u-to-480u - hole radii of sizes [4.40, 4.42, 4.44, 4.46, 4.38]
  • hole_tolerance_TOL500u-to-580u - hole radii of sizes [4.50, 4.52, 4.54, 4.56, 4.58]

description.text:
Currently (April 2017), I'm a PhD candidate at the Centre for Robotics and Neural Systems, Plymouth University, working with learning (or programming) by demonstration using Spiking Neural Networks (SNN) implemented as Liquid State Machines (LSM).

So, I designed this elastic pen holder because it's not so easy to teach a robot to draw using an uneven surface (although we have a paper based on LSM and Sensor Fusion that partially solves this problem). Also, Baxter was not designed to be super precise and its positional accuracy is +/-5mm.

Hint: you should be able to reuse the same screws from the vacuum or electrical grippers.

If you liked this thing, don't forget to visit my personal website: ricardodeazambuja.com

DISCLAIMER 1: use it at your own risk ;)
DISCLAIMER 2: Baxter is a cobot, but it is only safe to interact with people (when using Joint Position or Velocity control modes) if a risk assessment is done every time you add a new end effector. So, be careful if you decide to use this pen holder (don't forget about Disclaimer 1).
